title: 107_hr5596
content: Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments allow political committees of state or local candidates, as well as state or local committees of political parties, to be exempt from notification and reporting requirements. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempt qualified State or local political organizations from certain notification and reporting requirements. These organizations are defined as political organizations whose exempt functions solely aim to influence or attempt to influence. The term 'qualified State or local political organization' refers to a political organization focused on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public offices, subject to reporting requirements under State law. The curr_chunk provides information on expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved in a political organization. The curr_chunk discusses reporting requirements for organizations, including public availability of reports and disregarding certain state law differences. The curr_chunk discusses state law requirements for reporting contributions, with a focus on the maximum amount to be reported and exemptions from identifying certain details. The curr_chunk outlines the information required for reporting contributions and expenditures to an organization, including details such as the employer and occupation of contributors, recipients, purpose of expenditures, and dates of transactions. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions under which an organization can still be considered a qualified State or local political organization despite making minor errors in complying with reporting requirements. It also specifies that a federal candidate or office holder cannot control or participate significantly in such an organization to be considered qualified. The amendments made by this section specify that a federal candidate or office holder cannot control or participate significantly in a qualified State or local political organization. The effective date for these amendments is as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization. Amendment made to section 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding persons required to make income tax returns. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Amendments made to section 6104 of the Code regarding disclosure by the Secretary and public inspection of certain annual returns. Amendments made to section 6033 of the Internal Revenue Code regarding returns required by political organizations. Political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more are subject to annual returns. Qualified State or local political organizations have a threshold of $100,000. Political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more must file annual returns with specific information required by the IRS. Qualified State or local political organizations have a higher threshold of $100,000. Certain organizations are exempt from filing annual returns with the IRS if they fall under specific categories such as State or local political party committees, caucuses, candidate committees, national party committees, or campaign committees for federal office. Certain organizations, including political party committees, House or Senate campaign committees, political committees required to report under the Federal Election Campaign Act, and those falling under section 527 for tax purposes, may be exempt from filing information returns if the Secretary deems it unnecessary for efficient tax administration. Certain organizations, like political party committees, may be exempt from filing information returns if the Secretary deems it unnecessary for tax administration. The amendments made by this section will be effective as if included in Public Law 106-230. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, will publicize the effect of the amendments made by this Act and the interaction of reporting requirements under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided will be included in guidance issued to the public regarding reporting requirements for political organizations. Additionally, there will be a waiver of filing amounts. The amendment allows the Secretary to waive taxes or penalties for organizations failing to comply with disclosure requirements if the failure was due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exempt function income whether or not segregated. (b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Paragraph (1) of section 527(j) is amended to allow assessment and collection of penalties in the same manner as section 6652(c). (c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Subparagraph (A) of section 527(i)(1) is amended. Subtitle F imposes penalties in the same way as section 6652(c). Section 527(i)(1)(A) no longer requires duplicate written filings. Section 7207 now applies the fraud penalty to various sections. Section 527(j)(3) is amended to include additional information in reports. Section 527(j)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include additional information in reports, such as the amount, date, and purpose. Electronic filing is required for reports if contributions or expenditures exceed $50,000 in a calendar year. The Secretary must make notices and reports available for public inspection on the Internet within 48 hours of filing if contributions or expenditures exceed $50,000. The database of these documents must be searchable by specific items. The Secretary must make the database of notices and reports searchable by various items such as names, states, zip codes, contributors, recipients of expenditures, and time periods. The database must also be downloadable. The database of notices and reports must be searchable by various items and downloadable. Additionally, amendments are made regarding the contents of the notice and the timing of notice in case of material change. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require timely notification of any material changes in information, with a deadline of 30 days after the change. Failure to comply with this requirement will result in penalties. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require timely notification of material changes, with penalties for failure to comply. The amendments specify that in case of a failure related to a material change, income and deductions will only be considered from the date of the change until notice is given. Effective dates for the amendments vary depending on the subsection. The amendments made by this Act specify effective dates for various subsections, with changes applying to reports and notices required to be filed at different times. The amendments made by this Act specify effective dates for material changes filed on or after June 30, 2003. The amendments under subsection (g) apply to material changes on or after the enactment date of this Act, with a transition rule for changes within 30 days of enactment. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS ON EXISTING DISCLOSURES. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
